Comment: Clear and fun, a useful exercise for developing a parser considering operator precedence

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: A solid, clear and nice puzzle

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice puzzle, statement is clear & lots of tests/validators.
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!

Changes:
- Fixed some typos.
- A couple more tests (16 and 17).
- Added a random cover picture (https://members.loria.fr/JDumas/archives/school-projects/ocamlbike/).
- Rewrote the solution for validation in python.

When it comes to tags, this can also be solved with either a stack or (in python at least) the AST, but I feel like adding any of those would be unnecessarily confusing.

I think the puzzle is fine as it is but I'll give it another round of WIP because it's been quite some time since the last one.
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!
je pense que c'est une bonne id√©e !
It is pretty difficult to tell how chaining composition operators and operator precedence with + works from just the explanation. You would need to look at the test-cases/examples to find these out

Changes:
- Some minor tweaks to the statement.
- A couple more tests.
- Rewrote the solution for validation.

I decided to remove the "intuition" part. I'll post it here in case I change my mind again:

<<Intuition:>> 
Consider this PHP function:
`max(array_map('strlen', explode(" ", $string)))`
It follows the standard function composition notation. With our initial choice of symbols, it becomes:
`max . (array_map strlen) . explode`
In comparison, consider this <<equivalent>> Ruby function:
`string.split.map(&:length).max`
It uses reverse notation. With our initial choice of symbols, it becomes:
`split |> (map length) |> max`
(Notice that in "dot notation" used in Ruby the dot plays the role of the {{|>}}, and it should not be confused with our composition operator {{.}})

The reverse composition operator {{|>}} can be found in languages like OCaml and F#, or in Haskell with the notation ({{>>>}}). It also shares similarities with Bash piping {{|}}.
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!
I think this is very clear puzzle. I liked it.
I feel like the intuition part is not very clear, maybe the example part alone is fine?

I would suggest to retain the PHP and Ruby examples, discuss them in two separate paragraphs instead of mixing them together (which is a bit confusing to me right now).

Other comments:

Goal section
* Do you think whether . or + has a higher precedence should be mentioned?

Constraints section
* Please change "english" to "English".

Stub generator
* It's a bit weird to mention "haskell_to_OCaml"? Both languages are not mentioned anywhere else in the statement, and some other programming languages (e.g. F#) have similar features.

Thanks.
I liked this puzzle, statement is clear and easy to understand without the "intuition" part.
I'm a bit confused, what "operator precedence with +", whatever that may mean, required you to go to the test-cases (that was not a direct result of the statement examples)?

Fixed the capital letter and tried to reorganize the paragraphs.

Now for the precedence, I don't know, should I? It's the usual precedence of function compositions, I didn't any extra rule. Also the example should ideally solve this doubt if anything.

For the "haskell_to_OCaml", that was the original title and jist of the problem, but I ended up thinking it would scare some people away, so I remade the statement and changed my example to use more mainstream languages. It then stuck and, anyway, I think it's a harmless reference?

I know about F# but as I can recall they copied it from OCaml so I'd rather just let it as it is. Maybe I'll add a couple lines after the Intuition part with all of this:

"|>" is used in both OCaml and F#
The equivalent in Haskell is >>>
It shares similarities with bash piping | 

etc.

Thank you for making the changes and the response.

Sorry if my comment wasn't clear enough; I meant the PHP example and the Ruby example should be separated instead of mixed together.

That line in the stub generator is a harmless reference; it just feels odd to single out Haskell and OCaml ü§∑üèª As you said, F# and Bash contain similar features too, and Groovy as well (and maybe more, I haven't gone through all of this: https://rosettacode.org/wiki/Function_composition )

I've tried separating them but it looks awful, is it fine like this? Also added the aforementioned extra couple of lines.

They are singled out because, IIRC, they were the first in using this particular notation (not the general idea of composition ofc), that is, the dot for composition (Haskell) and the |> for reverse composition (OCaml).
It looks confusing to me...
Mmm, how would you do it?

Consider this PHP function:
max(array_map('strlen', explode(" ", $string)))

It follows the standard function composition notation. With our initial choice of symbols, it becomes:
max . (array_map strlen) . explode

In comparison, consider this Ruby function:
string.split.map(&:length).max

It uses reverse notation. With our initial choice of symbols, it becomes:
split |> (map length) |> max

(Notice that in "dot notation" used in Ruby the dot plays the role of the |>, and it should not be confused with our composition operator .)
Alright, shipped. I only added the bold "equivalent" and some formatting to the symbols. Thank you again.
Nice addition! Thanks.

Goal
* Suggest to change "exclusively the outcome of" to "expressed exclusively using".

* Note 3: I believe you're referring to
f . g + h vs
(f + h) . g vs
f . (g + h)? If so, please change "example" to "examples".

* Note 4: Suggest to change "well behaved" to "well-formed" (how an expression behaves is a different matter from how it is formed).

* Note 5: Suggest to change "test" to "expression".

Input
* Suggest to change "exclusively the outcome of" to "expressed exclusively using".

Thanks.
Fixed, thanks.
